questions.stem: Recurrent Airway Obstruction (RAO), also known as "heaves," is comparable to:

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in humans

questions.explanation: Recurrent Airway Obstruction (RAO), also known as "heaves," is comparable to asthma in humans. COPD (A), pneumonia (C), and tuberculosis (D) are not accurate comparisons.

questions.stem: RAO is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Mucus production leading to obstructive lung disease

options.label: D
options.text: Permanent lung fibrosis in all cases

questions.explanation: Permanent lung fibrosis does not occur in all cases of RAO. Airway inflammation (A), bronchoconstriction (B), and mucus production (C) are characteristic features.

questions.stem: RAO is most common in:

options.label: B
options.text: Stabled horses exposed to dust, hay, and straw

questions.explanation: RAO is most common in stabled horses exposed to dust, hay, and straw. Pasture horses (A), racehorses only (C), and foals (D) are not the most common group.

questions.stem: The average age of onset for RAO is:
questions.explanation: The average age of onset for RAO is 9 years. Younger ages (A, B) or older (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: RAO is triggered by inhaled environmental allergens such as:

options.label: B
options.text: Dust, molds, and organic particles in hay, straw, and bedding

questions.explanation: RAO is triggered by inhaled environmental allergens such as dust, molds, and organic particles in hay, straw, and bedding. Only pollen (A), viral particles (C), or bacterial spores (D) are not the primary triggers.

questions.stem: Which breeds have a genetic predisposition to RAO?
questions.explanation: Warmbloods and Lipizzaners have a genetic predisposition to RAO. Thoroughbreds and Arabians (A), Quarter Horses (C), or equal distribution (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Early/mild clinical signs of RAO include:

options.label: B
options.text: Occasional cough (especially during eating/exercise) and nasal discharge

questions.explanation: Early/mild clinical signs include occasional cough (especially during eating/exercise) and nasal discharge. Severe respiratory distress (A), complete exercise intolerance (C), or collapse (D) are severe signs.

questions.stem: Progressive/severe signs of RAO include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic cough, wheezing, and flared nostrils

options.label: B
options.text: Labored breathing with pronounced abdominal effort

questions.explanation: Profuse nasal discharge with blood is not a typical sign of RAO. Chronic cough and wheezing (A), labored breathing (B), and heave line (C) are progressive/severe signs.

questions.stem: The gold standard diagnostic test for RAO is:

options.label: C
options.text: Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) to retrieve airway secretions for cytology

questions.explanation: Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) to retrieve airway secretions for cytology is a key diagnostic test. CBC (A), radiography (B), and serology (D) are less specific.

questions.stem: Environmental trial for RAO diagnosis involves:

options.label: B
options.text: Removing horse from dusty setting and observing improvement

questions.explanation: Environmental trial involves removing the horse from dusty setting and observing improvement. Administering antibiotics (A), exercise testing (C), or blood gas analysis (D) are not environmental trials.

questions.stem: Primary treatment goal for RAO is:
questions.explanation: Primary treatment goal is to reduce allergen exposure. Eliminating all allergens permanently (A), curing completely (C), or preventing all episodes (D) are not realistic goals.

questions.stem: Feed management for RAO includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: High-quality hay, avoid moldy or dusty feed

options.label: B
options.text: Soak or steam hay before feeding

options.label: C
options.text: Feed at ground level to limit dust inhalation

options.label: D
options.text: Feed at chest height to limit dust inhalation

questions.explanation: Feeding at ground level is not recommended; feed should be at chest height to limit dust inhalation. High-quality hay (A), soaking/steaming hay (B), and feeding at chest height (D) are appropriate.

questions.stem: For pasture-related heaves (SPAOPD), horses should be:

options.label: B
options.text: Removed from pasture during hot, humid months

questions.explanation: For pasture-related heaves (SPAOPD), horses should be removed from pasture during hot, humid months. Keeping on pasture (A), antibiotics (C), or more exercise (D) are not appropriate.

questions.stem: Inhaled therapies for RAO include:

options.label: B
options.text: Corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation and bronchodilators to open airways

questions.explanation: Inhaled therapies include corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation and bronchodilators to open airways. Antibiotics (A), antivirals (C), and antifungals (D) are not inhaled therapies for RAO.

questions.stem: Systemic steroids for RAO should be used with caution because long-term use can lead to:
questions.explanation: Systemic steroids should be used with caution because long-term use can lead to laminitis, GI, and liver issues. Weight gain only (A), no side effects (C), or only mild side effects (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Oral bronchodilators used in RAO include:
questions.explanation: Oral bronchodilators used in RAO include clenbuterol. Penicillin (A), furosemide (C), and digoxin (D) are not bronchodilators.

questions.stem: Nutritional support for RAO may include:

options.label: B
options.text: Balanced vitamins and minerals, omega-3 fatty acids, and supplements like spirulina

questions.explanation: Nutritional support may include balanced vitamins and minerals, omega-3 fatty acids, and supplements like spirulina. High-fat diets (A), high-carbohydrate diets (C), or no support (D) are not appropriate.

questions.stem: The prognosis for RAO depends on:
questions.explanation: The prognosis depends on stage and management. Age only (A), breed only (C), or sex only (D) are not the determining factors.

questions.stem: With good management, horses with RAO can:

options.label: B
options.text: Live comfortably and perform light work

options.label: C
options.text: Return to full athletic performance immediately

questions.explanation: With good management, horses with RAO can live comfortably and perform light work. Never performing work (A), full athletic performance (C), or complete cure (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: RAO is:
questions.explanation: RAO is lifelong but manageable. It is not curable with antibiotics (A), preventable with vaccination (C), or only affects older horses (D).
